newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan opposition parties to demand new cabinet.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan opposition parties to demand new cabinet.

text.p: Taiwan's opposition lawmakers said on Thursday they would demand that the president appoint a new premier, escalating a political showdown amid a mounting public outcry over the island's worsening social order.

Lawmakers from the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party and the fledgling New Party sought support for a motion asking President Lee Teng-hui to call for a complete cabinet reshuffle and replace incumbent Premier Lien Chan.

"Public discontent is boiling. We want President Lee to name a new premier," Chen Chung-hsin, deputy secretary-general of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, told Reuters in a telephone interview.
"It is very inappropriate for the president to retain Lien Chan as premier and find a few scapegoats to take responsibility," Chen said. "This is not what the public wants. It's simply unacceptable."
A New Party official, who declined to be identified, said the party would support the Democratic Progressive Party's case.
Under Taiwan's political system, such a motion to the president would not be legally binding.

On Wednesday, Lee asked Lien to make some changes in cabinet positions next week in an effort to appease a public outcry over a spate of violent crimes. But he declined to accept Lien's resignation offer.
The discovery of the naked body of 17-year-old Pai Hsiao-yen, daughter of actress Pai Ping-ping, floating in a river last week caused a public outcry.
Police said 17-year-old Pai Hsiao-yen had been kidnapped and murdered. Her killers remained at large.
The murder followed a string of violent crimes since 1996.
More than 50,000 people marched in Taipei on Sunday to protest against Pai's murder and demand the resignation of Lien and a cabinet reshuffle.
Government spokesman Su Chi criticised the opposition, saying the parties had made a political issue of the murder of Pai Hsiao-yen.
Chen of the Democratic Progressive Party said: "The public has demanded a change. The ruling Nationalist Party cannot ignore the voice of the people."
As pressure for a new cabinet intensified, a popular Taiwan cabinet member announced his resignation on Thursday.
Ma Ying-jeou, minister without portfolio, said in a statement he had tendered his resignation "due to change of political ethics, obstacles in reforms and growing public discontent."

"Before the reforms can be achieved, political mores have already changed, with (officials) struggling for powers, taking credits and shunning responsibility," said the former justice minister, one of the most popular officials on the island.
State media have speculated that the ruling party wanted Ma to replace Interior Minister Lin Feng-cheng, who has been under fire for the recent upsurge in violent crime.
